message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The subcutaneous nodules, joint pain, and mitral regurgitation are classic signs of rheumatic fever, a complication of untreated or inadequately treated streptococcal pharyngitis. The ASO titer is elevated, indicating recent exposure to streptococcus. Rheumatic fever is a type II hypersensitivity reaction, in which antibodies directed against streptococcal antigens cross-react with normal host tissues, causing inflammation and tissue damage.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of subcutaneous nodules and a holosystolic murmur over the mitral area suggest rheumatic fever. Additionally, the elevated ASO titer and elevated inflammatory markers suggest an ongoing immune response. Rheumatic fever is caused by a type II hypersensitivity reaction, in which autoantibodies attack and damage heart tissue.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including joint pain and subcutaneous nodules, suggest rheumatic fever, which is caused by a type II hypersensitivity reaction. The elevated ASO titer also supports this diagnosis. Type I hypersensitivity reactions involve IgE antibodies, type III hypersensitivity reactions involve immune complexes, and congenital immunodeficiencies are not likely to present with these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical picture suggests rheumatic heart disease, which is a complication of untreated streptococcal pharyngitis. The presence of subcutaneous nodules and a localized holosystolic murmur points towards Type II hypersensitivity reaction. ASO titer > 200 IU also suggests a previous streptococcal infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and lab work suggest rheumatic fever, which is a complication of untreated streptococcal pharyngitis. The subcutaneous nodules suggest Type II hypersensitivity reaction, which involves antibody-mediated destruction of tissues.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The subcutaneous nodules and the holosystolic murmur over the mitral area suggest rheumatic fever, which is a type II hypersensitivity reaction. The elevated ASO titer and elevated inflammatory markers support the diagnosis. Type I hypersensitivity reaction involves IgE-mediated reactions, type III involves immune complex deposition, and congenital immunodeficiency would not explain all of the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, subcutaneous nodules, and the holosystolic murmur suggest that the most likely cause is rheumatic fever, which is a Type II hypersensitivity reaction. The elevated ASO levels also support this diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The boy’s symptoms, including exertional shortness of breath, joint pain, and subcutaneous nodules are consistent with rheumatic fever, which results from a type II hypersensitivity reaction to Streptococcus pyogenes. The elevated ASO and clinical findings support this diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including joint pain, shortness of breath, declining grades, and subcutaneous nodules are consistent with rheumatic fever, which is caused by a type II hypersensitivity reaction triggered by a prior streptococcal infection. The elevated ASO titer supports this diagnosis. Type I hypersensitivity reactions involve IgE and immediate allergic responses, whereas type III hypersensitivity reactions involve immune complex deposition in tissues. Congenital immunodeficiencies are not likely to present with these specific symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of subcutaneous nodules, a holosystolic murmur, and elevated ASO titer suggest a diagnosis of rheumatic fever, which is caused by a type II hypersensitivity reaction to Group A beta-hemolytic streptococcus. None of the other options fit the clinical presentation.
